16553 S0926-860X(18)30071-1 10.1016/j.apcata.2018.02.013 Elsevier B.V. Scheme 1 Synthesis of DPC via transesterification of n-propanol and DMC over catalyst. Scheme 1 Scheme 2 Possible reaction mechanism for the DPC synthesis from n-propanol and DMC over 0.5MgO-ZrO2 catalyst. Scheme 2 Fig. 1 XRD patterns of xMgO-ZrO2 catalysts: low angel (a); wide angle (b). Fig. 1 Fig. 2 N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms (a) and pore-size distributions (b) of xMgO-ZrO2 catalysts. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 TEM images of fresh 0.5MgO-ZrO2 and 0.5MgO-ZrO2-fourth samples. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 CO2-TPD of xMgO-ZrO2 and ZrO2 catalysts. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 The correlation between n-propanol conversion and the total number of surface basic sites for various catalysts. Reaction conditions: 40 mmol n-propanol, 20 mmol DMC, 120 °C, 2 h, 0.2 g catalyst. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Influence of reaction conditions on the DPC synthesis over 0.5MgO-ZrO2 catalyst. One-pot template-free preparation of mesoporous MgO-ZrO2 catalyst for the synthesis of dipropyl carbonate Xuelan Zhang a ⁎ Dengfeng Wang a ⁎ Gongde Wu b ⁎ Xiaoli Wang b Xixi Jiang a Shanfang Liu a Diangen Zhou a Dongmei Xu c ⁎ Jun Gao c a College of Chemistry, Chemical Engineering and Materials Science, Zaozhuang University, Zaozhuang, 277160, PR China College of Chemistry Chemical Engineering and Materials Science Zaozhuang University Zaozhuang 277160 PR China b School of Environment and Technology, Nanjing Institute of Technology, Nanjing, 211167, PR China School of Environment and Technology Nanjing Institute of Technology Nanjing 211167 PR China c College of Chemical and Environmental Engineering, Shandong University of Science and Tehnnology, Qingdao, 266590, PR China College of Chemical and Environmental Engineering Shandong University of Science and Tehnnology Qingdao 266590 PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract A series of mesoporous nano-MgO-ZrO2 with various Mg:Zr atomic ratios were prepared via simple co-precipitation process without addition of a template. It was demonstrated by XRD, N2 adsorption-desorption and TEM that these samples still kept well mesoporous structure even after calcination at 600 °C. During the preparation process, divalent Mg2+ ions could be incorporated into tetragonal ZrO2 lattice to form a solid solution. More important, the surface basic density of these catalysts closely depended on their Mg content. Then, the resulting MgO-ZrO2 catalysts were used as basic catalysts for the dipropyl carbonate (DPC) synthesis via transesterification of n-propanol and dimethyl carbonate. The relationship between the basic property of solid base and their catalytic performance was clarified in detail. Among all the materials, the catalyst with Mg:Zr atomic ratio = 0.5 showed the best catalytic performance. Under the suitable reaction conditions, the yield of DPC could reach 98.5% with 100% selectivity. In addition, based on the reusability test and catalyst characterization, this catalyst exhibited extraordinary structure stability and it could be reused at least four times without obvious loss of reactivity. Keywords Dipropyl carbonate Transesterification MgO-ZrO2 Template-free 1 Introduction As an important member of the dialkyl carbonate, dipropyl carbonate (DPC) is attracting much attention due to its remarkable physical-chemical properties. It is capable to substitute some hazardous reagents more efficiently and environmentally as a useful propylating and propoxycarbonylating agent for the production of numerous organic chemicals. Besides, a wide variety application of DPC has been demonstrated in fields of solvents and additives [1–4]. Importantly, in comparison with dimethyl carbonate (DMC) and diethyl carbonate, DPC has higher molecular weight, higher flash point and stronger anti-oxidation ability, thus, it is considered as a more stable and safe electrolyte in lithium batteries under more extreme circumstance such as high temperature and oxygen environment [5]. Therefore, great efforts should be devoted to achieve the effective production of DPC. Conventionally, DPC was synthesized via phosgenation of n-propanol in 1941 [6]. However, this method was not eco-friendly because that phosgene was a colorless, corrosive and highly toxic gas. So, an environmental benign routine should be developed for the DPC synthesis. Recently, DMC, which was known as a green building block with mild toxicity for living organisms, has attracted much attention from researchers [7,8]. It has been applied as an organic synthesis intermediate to replace highly toxic phosgene, dimethyl sulfate and methyl halides without environmental pollution [9,10]. Especially, DMC has ability to avoid the shortcomings of carbonylation with phosgene including a long industrial process, complex reaction routine, high toxicity, severe pollution and generation of too many undesired products. Consequently, all these merits make application of DMC as carbonylating agent very attractive for esterification and transesterification reaction in carbonylation process [11,12], and certainly, the synthesis of DPC from DMC and n-propanol is an environmental benign approach. Many researchers have studied the production of both dialkyl carbonate and cyclic carbonate via transesterification employing DMC as the raw material [13–16]. Various homogeneous catalysts including bases, organic Sn, Mo or Ti compounds could promote the transesterification reactions in the liquid phase [17–19]. Unfortunately, this procedure suffered an unavoidable weakness ascribed to the inconvenient catalyst separation. Hence, it is desirable to develop a solid heterogeneous catalyst with high activity and stability for the transesterification. As per our best knowledge, there existed few literatures focused on the manufacture of DPC via transesterification with DMC and n-propanol. Li et al. disclosed that KNO3/MCM-48 showed good catalytic performance for the DPC synthesis, but the catalyst preparation process was very complicated and the mesoporous MCM-48 was not stable during the reaction [20]. Chen et al. investigated the production of methyl propyl carbonate (MPC) using supported TiO2/Al2O3 via gas-phase transesterification. However, DPC was only the co-product with very low selectivity [21]. Recently, Ma et al. found that Mg-Al-La mixed oxide catalytic materials could give 93.9% yield of DPC, but a long time (6 h) was needed with high cost of catalyst due to expensive rare earth metal (La) [22]. Thereby, it is still a challenging task to develop a high active and stable heterogeneous catalyst that is prepared through a simple and repeatable way for the synthesis of DPC via transestification. According to previous reports, it was disclosed that the catalytic ability of catalysts towards the transesterification process originated from their surface basic sites [22–25]. Therefore, it is reasonable to explore solid basic catalytic samples for the DPC synthesis. Although pure metal oxide such as CaO, MgO and La2O3 could be used as basic catalysts, they possessed low specific area and vulnerability to water and carbon dioxide in air, which to some extent restricted their application [26–28]. In order to overcome these shortcomings, selecting suitable carrier for the solid base catalyst was quite critical, for some supporting materials would negatively influence the basic and stable property of the catalyst. Among many potential candidates, zirconia was considered as an ideal carrier for basic guest species, and numerous zirconia-based mixed oxides have been investigated to catalyze many reactions [29–31]. Particularly, mesoporous MgO-ZrO2 catalysts with high surface area and stability were prepared for the synthesis of propylene glycol methyl ether. Nevertheless, the expensive zirconium (IV) n-propoxide and pluronic P123 were, respectively used as Zr source and template reagent [32,33]. Moreover, the catalyst preparation process was quite complicated via sol-gel method. Thus, these weaknesses have enormously limited its further application in industrial production, and a cheap and simple preparation method is highly required. In this work, a series of MgO-ZrO2 catalysts with various Mg:Zr molar ratios were obtained via simple co-precipitation method without a template. It was displayed by N2 adsorption-desorption that all these samples possessed mesoporous structure and high surface area. Simultaneously, their basic properties were strongly related to the Mg content in the catalysts. Moreover, we will show that the MgO-ZrO2 materials are efficient solid basic catalysts for the DPC synthesis from DMC and n-propanol with selectivity of 100% under moderate and solvent-free conditions. The relationship between the textural, chemical structures as well as basic properties of catalysts and their catalytic performance were elucidated. Besides, the optimization of reaction conditions was attempted over the model catalyst. Furthermore, the catalyst recyclability was studied in detail based on reused test and catalyst characterization. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The mesoporous MgO-ZrO2 catalysts were obtained via simple co-precipitation method without a template. The initial Mg2+:Zr4+ atomic ratio in the mother solution varied from 0.1 to 1.0. The typical preparation route could be described as follows: two 100 mL aqueous solution, a solution containing Mg(NO3)2∙6H2O and Zr(NO3)4∙5H2O, another one containing suitable amount of NaOH without surfactant template, were added dropwise into 100 mL deionized water with vigorous stirring at room temperature. The pH value was kept at 11 during this procedure. Afterwards, the product was aged for 2 h under stirring under ambient conditions, then filtered and washed with deionized water until neutral pH value was reached. Subsequently, the filter cakes were refluxed in de-ionized water at 80 °C for 48 h, and then filtered, dried at 100 °C overnight. Finally, the final mixed oxide catalytic samples with various Mg:Zr atomic ratios were obtained after calcination at 600 °C for 5 h. The as-prepared MgO-ZrO2 catalysts were denoted as xMgO-ZrO2, where x was the nominal Mg2+:Zr4+ atomic ratio in the mother solution. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The surface areas of catalyst were measured by N2 adsorption-desorption technique at liquid nitrogen temperature, −196 °C, using a Micromeritics ASAP-2020 instrument. Prior to acquisition of the adsorption isotherm, samples degassing was conducted at 300 °C for 3 h under vacuum. The BET isotherm and BJH model were selected to calculate the specific surface area and pore volume, respectively. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) experiments were carried out on a Rigaku Miniflex diffractometer using Ni-filtered Cu Kα radiation at room temperature (with a step of 4°/min in a 2θ range of 5–80°). All the XRD peaks were assigned according to the Joint Committee Powder Diffraction Standard Card (JCPDS Card). The elemental chemical analysis was analyzed using an inductively coupled plasma-optical (ICP) emission spectroscopy (PerkinElmer ICP OPTIMA-3000). High resolution transmission electron microscopy (TEM) image were obtained on a transmission electron microscope (FEI Tecnai F20) with a field emission gun operating at 200 kV. The basic property of catalysts was detected by CO2 temperature programmed desorption (CO2-TPD). 0.20 g catalysts were taken in a quartz reactor bed and pretreated in a flow of Ar (40 mL/min) at 600 °C for 2 h. After cooled to room temperature, the samples were exposed to pure CO2 for 2 h using a six-way valve. After the physically adsorbed CO2 was purged off by Ar flow, the CO2-TPD experiments were carried out from 30 to 600 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. 2.3 Catalytic test The transesteritication reaction of n-propanol with DMC was conducted in a 50 mL stainless autoclave with a magnetic stirrer. Typically, 40 mmol n-propanol, 20 mmol DMC and 0.2 g fresh catalyst were put into the reactor. Then, the reactor was heated to 120 °C in a short time and kept at this temperature for 3 h under stirring. After the reaction, the reactor was cooled to room temperature, and the product was weighted. Afterwards, the mixture was separated by centrifugation to remove the solid catalyst, and the liquid product was analyzed on a gas chromatograph (Aglient-6820) with a SE-54 capillary column and a flame ionization detector (FID). The column temperature was programmed to have a 3 min initial hold at 60 °C, a 20 °C/min ramp from 60 to 150 °C, and a 3 min hold at 150 °C. Meanwhile, all products detected in the liquid were identified by a GC–MS (Agilent 7890-7000B) equipped with an HP-5MS capillary column (30 m). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural and textual properties of the prepared catalysts Fig. 1 (a) presents the low angel XRD patterns of MgO-ZrO2 with various Mg:Zr atomic ratios. Apparently, all the samples exhibited a distinct diffraction at around 2θ = 1°, implying that the catalytic materials had mesoporous structure [29]. Moreover, it could be easily found that this peak became weaker and broader with increasing of x from 0.1 to 1.0, which revealed that the increasing Mg content was not favorable for the catalyst mesoporous structure. This was in line with the results reported in the previous work [33]. The wide angle XRD patterns of samples are demonstrated in Fig. 2 (b). According to Schuth et al., zirconia only existed in monoclinic phase, and tetragonal phase was metastable below 1170 °C [34]. With temperature increasing, tetragonal phase was inclined to convert into the monoclinic phase. Nevertheless, in this study, tetragonal ZrO2 (t-ZrO2) instead of monoclinic phase was detected after thermal treatment at 600 °C. This phenomenon was attributed to the positive effect of incorporation of Mg2+ on the stability of t-ZrO2. More important, it was known that Mg2+ ions could replace some Zr4+ ions in the host lattice, giving rise to generation of a stable homogeneous MgO-ZrO2 solid solution when Mg2+ ions were introduced into t-ZrO2 support [32]. Therefore, as the Mg:Zr atomic ratio was in the range of 0–0.5, all the catalytic samples presented a strong and broad diffraction assigned to t-ZrO2 at 2θ of 30° without appearance of diffraction lines of MgO or monoclinic ZrO2. Additionally, two small diffractions for t-ZrO2 also appeared at 2θ of 50° and 60°. However, their intensity and sharpness gradually decreased with rise of Mg content. In case of 1.0MgO-ZrO2 sample, two peaks at 2θ of 43.2° and 62.5°, which could be assigned to periclase MgO-like structure (PDF No. 45-946), were detected. This was because that the ZrO2 carrier could not support any further MgO dissolution into its lattice as excessive Mg2+ was added into the system. As a result, free MgO crystals were formed on the surface of this catalyst. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were applied to measure the pore structure of these mixed oxide catalysts. Fig. 2 gives the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and their corresponding pore size distribution. Evidently, all the catalytic samples presented typical IV isotherms with hysteresis loops at higher relative pressure according to the IUPAC recommendation, suggesting that mesoporous frameworks with facile pore connectivity were formed for them [35]. Moreover, it should be mentioned that the content of Mg could affect their hysteresis loops enormously. For 0.1MgO-ZrO2 and 0.25MgO-ZrO2 materials, their isotherms had similar profile of typical IV isotherms and H2 shaped hysteresis loop with P/P0 between 0.5–0.9, implying appearance of ordered mesoporous structure, which was caused by accumulation of nano-particles [36]. However, with regard to Mg-rich sample (i.e., 1.0MgO-ZrO2), its isotherm clearly showed a H3 hysteresis loop when value of P/P0 was in the range of 0.7–1.0. This indicated that slit-like pore was generated in this material because of the aggregated particles. As to 0.5 MgO-ZrO2, the hysteresis loop generally retained a H2 shape but with higher opening and closing P/P0 value resembled to H3 type [37]. All these phenomena revealed that the mesoporous framework of catalysts became unordered with increase of Mg content, which was in accordance with the results of XRD in Fig. 1(a). In addition, with aim to clarify the formation process of pore framework for these catalysts, the pore size distribution from the desorption branch of the isotherms was calculated by the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method (see Fig. 2(b)). Apparently, substantially developed porous structures were formed for all the samples after heat treatment at 600 °C and the pore distribution was greatly related to the Mg content. Sharp pore volume distribution in a narrow and smaller pore diameter range was seen for catalytic materials with low Mg content, while Mg-rich samples showed broad distribution peak of pore structure with larger pore diameter. The specific surface area and pore volume of the catalysts are given in Table 1 . All the catalysts showed high BET surface areas owing to mesoporous structure. Consequently, it was favorable for exposing more active sites, resulting in improvement of their catalytic ability. However, the incorporation of Mg2+ led to an obvious decrease of surface area. The variation of porous structure above-mentioned could account for this phenomenon. Furthermore, it should be noted that their surface area decreased in the following sequence: 0.1MgO-ZrO2 > 0.25MgO-ZrO2 > 0.5MgO-ZrO2 > 1.0MgO-ZrO2. The typical TEM images of the as-prepared 0.5MgO-ZrO2 catalyst are shown in Fig. 3 , which further confirmed that the mesoporous framework was generated. It was clearly to see that this catalyst mainly exhibited sponge-like network formed via the connecting of nanoparticles, and the thickness of wall was about 10 nm. As shown in Fig. 3(b), continuous pore and channel of mesoporous material was detected with width of 4–10 nm. Moreover, no obvious crystalline phase were found and amorphous structures were dominant for this catalyst in the high multiple image. Generally speaking, the thermal stability of mesoporous zirconia was very poor. For this reason, the framework was easily to collapse and the mesopore tended to disappear after calcination under relatively high temperature. However, in this work, the MgO-ZrO2 nano-composite possessed distinct insensitivity to high temperature and it still kept mesoporous structure even after thermal treatment at 600 °C. Its remarkable stability might be owing to the deionized water refluxing during the synthesis process [38]. Similar experimental results were also reported in previous work, in which Chen et al. investigated the effect of deionized water refluxing on the thermal stability of mesoporous zirconia-based catalysts [39]. Therefore, it could be concluded that the as-prepared MgO-ZrO2 samples synthesized via facile co-precipitation method without template also had typical mesoporous structure and high surface area as those that obtained via complicated sol-gel method using P123 as template. Thus, the catalysts in the present work presented a more promising prospect for practical application. 3.2 Surface basic property To study the basic property of MgO-ZrO2 catalysts, CO2-TPD measurements were conduced. Basic strength and total basicity of the catalysts could be evaluated according to this characterization. Higher desorption temperature implied stronger basic strength, and higher CO2 desorption suggested more surface basicity [40]. Fig. 4 illustrates the typical CO2-TPD profiles of the catalytic materials. Evidently, all the curves could be splitted into two main Gaussian peaks. The first peak below 200 °C was related to the interaction of CO2 with weak basic sites, which were associated with hydroxyl group on the surface. The second peak between 200 and 600 °C could be assigned to combination of medium and strong basic sites, which were attributed to metal-oxygen pairs (including Mg-O and Zr-O) and low-coordination oxygen atoms (O2−) [23,41,42]. The basic site distributions as well as total basicity are listed in Table 1. Upon addition of Mg, the basic strength of MgO-ZrO2 catalysts became stronger compared to that of pure ZrO2, since their peak positions shifted to higher temperature. Importantly, the peak of weak sites tended to be weaker, whereas that of medium and strong basic sites became more intense with increasing Mg content. In particular, the contribution of medium and strong basic sites to the total basic sites of 1.0MgO-ZrO2 was about 1.6 times that of Mg-free sample (ZrO2). Thus, this demonstrated that for these catalytic samples, more medium and strong basic sites were present on their surface with addition of Mg2+. With respect to the total number of basic sites, one could see that it increased markedly first with rise of Mg2+ content until Mg2+:Zr4+ = 0.5, and then decreased with further increase of x. This might be ascribed to that the influence of the incorporation of Mg2+ on the total amount of basic sites were double-faced. On the one hand, introduction of Mg2+ undoubtedly increased the amount of metal-oxygen pairs (Mg-O), giving rise to rise of the number of medium basic sites for these catalysts. Meanwhile, during the process of catalyst preparation, the magnesium and zirconium nitrates as well as precipitant were mixed together and formed the precipitation. After drying and calcination, some Zr4+ was replaced by Mg2+ in the t-ZrO2 lattice. Due to that Zr4+ were more positive than Mg2+, the decrease of O1s binding energy would lead to the improvement of charge density of O2−, resulting in increase of number of strong basic site [32]. On the other hand, as the discussion above, the mesoporous structure of catalysts was gradually damaged with rise of amount of Mg2+. Besides, similar trend was also demonstrated for the BET surface area. Consequently, less basic sites were exposed for these catalytic samples. The former might be a predominant factor when x was from 0.1 to 0.5, while the latter would surpass the former as the atomic ratio of Mg2+:Zr4+ increased to 1.0. Considering the amount of weak basic sites was almost constant in value (except for 1.0MgO-ZrO2 sample), the variation of total basicity presented a volcanic shape. More important, it should be mentioned that their basic densities decreased in this order: 0.5MgO-ZrO2 > 1.0 MgO-ZrO2 > 0.25 MgO-ZrO2 > 0.1 MgO-ZrO2 > ZrO2. Therefore, it was reasonable to state that the insertion of Mg2+ into ZrO2 could enhance the surface basic property of catalysts, which would further promote their catalytic activity greatly. 3.3 Catalytic performance The synthesis of DPC via transesterification of DMC and n-propanol over catalysts was a typical stepwise reaction which could be described as follows: first, the n-propyl group in n-propanol substituted the methyl group of DMC to generate the intermediate MPC. Then, MPC further reacted with another n-propanol molecule to obtain final product DPC [20,22]. In addition to the major path and product, dipropyl ether (DPE) was detected by GCMS as another by-product in the present work at high temperature. It was generated via thermal decomposition of DPC, accompanying a release of CO2 (see Scheme 1 ). This phenomenon was also disclosed in the previous literature [43]. 3.3.1 Influence of Mg content on the DPC synthesis The catalytic performance of various catalysts for the DPC synthesis is summarized in Table 2 . It should be noted that the by-product DPE was not detected no matter what catalyst was used to catalyze DPC synthesis at 120 °C after 3 h reaction. Apparently, this reaction could take place to some extent even without catalyst, but the DPC yield was only 8.6%. Under the same reaction conditions, ZrO2 could give 60.9% n-propanol conversion. However, the selectivity and yield of DPC were only 40.6% and 24.7%, respectively. The main by-product was MPC with high yield of 36.2%. Upon the introduction of Mg, the n-propanol conversion was improved significantly. Nevertheless, the DPC yield differed remarkably among them. When 0.1MgO-ZrO2 was used as the catalyst, the DPC yield was about 43.6%, which was still far from satisfactory. With increasing of Mg content, both the n-propanol conversion and DPC yield increased sharply. In contrast, the MPC selectivity decreased enormously. Especially, the DPC yield reached a maximum value of 98.5% over 0.5MgO-ZrO2 with an excellent selectivity of 100%. When the Zr content further increased, both n-propanol conversion and DPC selectivity decreased obviously. Consequently, 1.0MgO-ZrO2 sample only gave 86.9% DPC yield. So, the current catalytic evaluation presented that the incorporation of Mg into ZrO2 could promote their catalytic ability towards the DPC synthesis via the transesterification of DMC and n-propanol. 3.3.2 Influence of basic property on the DPC synthesis In theory, the catalytic ability of catalysts was proportional to their BET surface area, for higher surface area facilitated exposing more active sites, which resulted in achieving higher reactivity. Based on the discussion above-mentioned, the BET surface area of catalysts decreased as increasing of Mg content. Nevertheless, their catalytic ability followed this order: 0.5MgO-ZrO2 > 1.0MgO-ZrO2 > 0.25MgO-ZrO2 > 0.1MgO-ZrO2 > ZrO2. Therefore, it was reasonable to draw a conclusion that BET surface area was not the decisive factor for this reaction. After extensive screening, a good correlation between the catalytic activity after reaction 2 h and the total amount of surface basic sites was established (see Fig. 5 ). Notably, the reactivity of n-propanol and DMC increased when more basic sites were available on the catalyst surface. The samples with a small number of basic sites, e.g. ZrO2 and 0.1MgO-ZrO2, exhibited low catalytic ability towards this reaction, whereas strongly basic materials presented high activity, even above 85% n-propanol conversion over 0.5MgO-ZrO2 catalyst. Based on the above-mentioned results and discussion, it could be concluded that this was a pure base catalyzed reaction and the possible reaction mechanism could be depicted in Scheme 2 . First, the n-propanol molecule was activated via the abstraction of H δ + by the basic sites, resulting in generation of a strong nucleophilic anion of propyloxy group. Meanwhile, DMC was coordinated with the cationic Mg or Zr surface atom through the oxygen atom of carbonyl group. Afterwards, the oxygen atom in the propyloxy group attacked the electrophilic carbonyl carbon of activated DMC to produce the intermediate MPC with release of a methanol molecule. Finally, similar to the mechanism of MPC generation, the product of DPC was synthesized as the result of interaction between MPC and another n-propanol molecule. We truly believe that this reaction follow this mechanism, since the intermediate MPC was detected and similar results have been disclosed by others [20,22]. In addition, the importance of basic property of catalyst for the carbonate synthesis via transesterification reaction has been also suggested by other studies. Liu et al. disclosed that the high activity of transition metal modified Mg-Al mixed oxides in DMC transesterification with glycerol could be attributed to their high surface basic density [23]. Very recently, Gandara-Loe et al. concluded that the catalytic materials presented high activity for the synthesis DMC via the transesterification due to their basic properties [44]. 3.3.3 Influence of reaction parameters In addition, the reaction parameters including reaction temperature, reaction time and catalyst amount were further optimized for the 0.5MgO-ZrO2 catalyst. Besides, the catalytic performance under various reaction conditions results containing deviation is shown in Table S1. 3.3.3.1 Influence of reaction temperature Fig. 6 (a) shows the effect of reaction temperature on the catalytic performance of 0.5MgO-ZrO2 catalyst. Clearly, the n-propanol conversion continuously increased with the increase of reaction temperature. Nevertheless, the DPC selectivity showed a maximum value at 120 °C and then, there was an obvious decrease for it. Correspondingly, the yield of DPC also presented the similar trend during this process. The decreased DPC yield and selectivity at high temperature indicated that side-reaction (thermal decomposition of DPC) might occur on the basic sites [43]. Accordingly, although the undesired product DPE was not detected at 120 °C, as the reaction temperature increased, its selectivity increased significantly at the cost of DPC consumption. Thus, the suitable reaction temperature was chosen as 120 °C. 3.3.3.2 Influence of reaction time The effect of reaction time on the catalytic activity of 0.5MgO-ZrO2 is illustrated in Fig. 6(b). It was found that the conversion of n-propanol and the yield of DPC increased gradually within the first 3 h. Meanwhile, the MPC selectivity reach its maximum value of 38.5% at 1 h, but decreased significantly with the reaction proceeding, implying that it was the intermediate for the DPC synthesis. As the reaction time prolonged to 4 h, a slight decrease of DPC yield was observed. This suggested that the by-reaction of DPE formation surpassed gradually the formation of DPC from n-propanol and DMC. Therefore, the preferable reaction time was 3 h. 3.3.3.3 Influence of catalyst amount Fig. 6(c) presents the influence of catalyst amount on the transesterification reaction. With the increasing catalyst amount, the n-propanol conversion increased gradually, whereas the DPC yield and selectivity reached their peak values at the catalyst amount of 0.2 g. When the catalyst amount further increased to 0.25 g, the DPC yield showed a slight decrease, which might be due to the fact that the reaction was close to equilibrium. Herein, 0.2 g was selected as the suitable catalyst amount in this work. 3.4 Stability of 0.5MgO-ZrO2 catalyst In view of the industrial application, not only high initial catalytic ability, but also good stability of the catalyst was required. For solid base catalysts, the stability was an important criterion when they were used in the practical reaction. Therefore, in order to acquire the information on the stability of mesoporous 0.5MgO-ZrO2 catalyst, the reusability of catalyst was also tested. After each reaction, the catalyst was separated from the reaction mixture by filtration, washed with methanol several times, dried in an oven at 100 °C then directly used for the next run. The recyclability of 0.5MgO-ZrO2 catalyst for the DPC synthesis is shown in Fig. 7 . As observed in the figure, about 64.6% n-propanol conversion was acquired after 3 h reaction with both fresh catalyst (1st run) and the catalyst reused for four times. More important, the variation between the DPC selectivity obtained on these two samples could be negligible in the present case. Moreover, the recovered catalyst after reused four times (0.5MgO-ZrO2-fourth) was characterized by means of XRD, TEM, N2 adsorption-desorption and CO2-TPD techniques. To our delight, TEM analysis displayed that the sponge-like network was unchanged (see Fig. 3(c)). XRD results showed that its diffraction peak number was the same as the fresh one (see Fig. 1(b)). Moreover, the BET surface area of 0.5MgO-ZrO2-fourth was found to change little compared to that of the fresh catalyst (180 m2 g−1). More important, CO2-TPD further confirmed that 0.5MgO-ZrO2-fourth still kept high number of basic sites (198 μmol g−1). Herein, it could be proved that 0.5MgO-ZrO2 catalytic material possessed excellent reusability and structure stability for the DPC synthesis from n-propanol and DMC. On the basis of the results above-mentioned and previous literature, the high amounts of basic sites were mainly generated by insertion of Mg2+ into the t-ZrO2 lattice [32,33]. Therefore, such active sites were firmly anchored to the substrate, which made this type of basic sites highly resistant to deactivation. Herein, the mesoporous MgO-ZrO2 solid base showed remarkably activity and stability for the DPC synthesis. 4 Conclusion A series of nano-crystalline MgO-ZrO2 solid base with ordered mesoporous structure were successfully synthesized via a template-free refluxing co-precipitation method. The basic property of these catalysts could be fine-tuned by simple adjustment of the Mg content, and a volcano variation trend on the total number of basic sites was observed with increasing of Mg:Zr atomic ratio. Moreover, the incorporation of Mg2+ into ZrO2 lattice resulted in the formation of solid solution, which could promote the catalyst structure stability for the reaction. The catalytic performance of these catalysts for the DPC synthesis from n-propanol and DMC was related to the amount of Mg content, the surface basic density and the reaction conditions. More important, the n-propanol conversion was demonstrated to increase in parallel with the total amount of basic sites. When 0.5MgO-ZrO2 catalyst was used, the n-propanol conversion could reach 98.5% with 100% selectivity towards DPC because of its maximum basicity. Thus, it could state that 0.5MgO-ZrO2 sample was a stable and practical catalyst for DPC synthesis via n-propanol transesterification with DMC. coredata.dc:description: A series of mesoporous nano-MgO-ZrO2 with various Mg:Zr atomic ratios were prepared via simple co-precipitation process without addition of a template. It was demonstrated by XRD, N2 adsorption-desorption and TEM that these samples still kept well mesoporous structure even after calcination at 600 °C. During the preparation process, divalent Mg2+ ions could be incorporated into tetragonal ZrO2 lattice to form a solid solution. More important, the surface basic density of these catalysts closely depended on their Mg content. Then, the resulting MgO-ZrO2 catalysts were used as basic catalysts for the dipropyl carbonate (DPC) synthesis via transesterification of n-propanol and dimethyl carbonate. The relationship between the basic property of solid base and their catalytic performance was clarified in detail. Among all the materials, the catalyst with Mg:Zr atomic ratio = 0.5 showed the best catalytic performance. Under the suitable reaction conditions, the yield of DPC could reach 98.5% with 100% selectivity. In addition, based on the reusability test and catalyst characterization, this catalyst exhibited extraordinary structure stability and it could be reused at least four times without obvious loss of reactivity.
coredata.dc:title: One-pot template-free preparation of mesoporous MgO-ZrO2 catalyst for the synthesis of dipropyl carbonate
